Warren Buffet has been talking about the difference between intrinsic value and market value for many decades. The market is a voting machine in the short term and a weighing machine in the long term. And in the long term we are all dead.

It's not new news that humans are neither rational nor efficient. What still surprises me is how few people even understand that a reasonable valuation for a stock is the discounted price of future earnings. When many stocks don't even pay earnings. Lets face it the market is full of speculators not investors.

The more liquid the market the more the small group of investors can eat the speculators for lunch over the long term. But small markets over the short term are rife with deviations which can be taken advantage by those whose costs for analysis and action is lower than others.

For many households it should be possible to provide for all your electricity needs using solar panels.
My solar panels did pay for all the electricity I used (in an all-electric house), until I got an electric car and my usage obviously increased. I should be able to get a few more panels in the near future to make up the difference (and more).

No I am not willing to give up my Prius while people drive around me going 95 mph in Hummers still, screaming "I am so selfish" with every mile; but I did give up meat, turn down my thermostat and wear a sweater inside all the time, among numerous other efforts to reduce my personal footprint. A very cold night or a poor seed season will kill vast numbers of birds, but the greatest losses are probably from habitat loss. Few birds may die when farmers plow every bit of open ground for corn, but they will have no place to nest. The song of bob white quail used to common all over the Midwest because farmers left some fields fallow every year and less productive land was not planted. The bob whites are largely gone, not because anyone killed them, but because they no longer have a place to live.

We've tried that 'capital distribution' thing in the past, but the fact that it's a 'survival of the fittest' game always seems to bias the winnings towards the top predators. Those who focus primarily on the game stand a better chance of winning the game.

An interesting side note, is that corporations are actually de facto Kingdoms in which we've provided a venue to vent the energy and desires of wannabe Kings and Emperors in a civilized manner. One problem would seem to be that technology and national economic success has given the 'Kingdoms' the keys to the world.

At some level, economic progress does 'float all boats', but as the size of the boats grow, some boats (by hook or by crook) find it reasonable to justify running over masses of smaller boats on the road to new profits. Kings and Emperors always do that if they can.

Vote Republican and enter the lottery that may win you a big boat..........or NOT!

Rather than too much Pickety-Krugmanist Franco heavy hand (see where it got the mother country), here is what I would suggest:

1. Technology has created a lot of opportunity already. To get a larger slice of the population to take advantage of it, find ways to make capital more widely accessible, and to create social equity. In short, democratize entrepreneurship. In today's world, look around, there is some opportunity (often enabled by technological based infrastructure, but not necessarily itself anything more than a straightfoward service business) that if taken could be a viable small business. Many of these niches are not being served partly because capital is accessible only to few. If more small/micro businesses were born and thrived, more jobs would be created. And as important, if these businesses were being formed by Joe Blow in neighborhoods all over America, rather than just the few who have access to capital, the wealth would be spread wider.

2. Technology is going to continue cutting both ways. For example in the next decade or so, a lot of people who drive trucks, taxis etc for a living are going to be out of a job. Uber & co are only what precedes the actual self driving intelligent vehicles. Technology needs to be infused across the education system. The more of the population are technically sound, the more productive the economy, and the better the wages will be. Technical high schools, which are already being repositioned could play a role here

The more expensive it becomes to mount a political campaign, the more influence is wielded by corporations with deep pockets and billionaires like the Koch Brothers -- and the worse off for individual citizens whose power lies only in their VOTE, not in their wallets.

The big industries -- Oil, Banking, Big Agra, whatever -- keep the politicians jumping at the lobbyists' dollars like hungry dogs at a scrap of bloody meat. The more expensive and out of control the election process is (by "out of control" I mean unlimited funds from any source that lies outside the authority of the public purse), the less represented the voters are in what used to be the finest democracy on earth. The connection between the citizen-voter and the elected representative is severed.

We just witnessed the most expensive mid-term election cycle in history. Money has flowed like a torrent. The funders now must be repaid. This is not democracy. This is government by the wealth owners.

Democracy would be well served to get rid of ALL lobbyists and let the government work according to the will of the people. People are the entities who cast ballots in the attempt to find solutions for national problems; they answer the call to fight in the services; they shed blood and sometimes die for their country. They are mortal.

To the Supreme Court: Giving immortal corporations the political influence to override the will of the people is your everlasting disgrace!

Don't blame the voter (or the non voter). The caliber of candidates on ballots is very low. I suspect a contributing factor to the dearth of ethical and civic minded politicians is the amount of money needed to run for office; I would think a truly ethical person, solely dedicated to serving the interests of the populace, would not sell his/her services.

And I wouldn't single out Southern Republicans. The Dems are no different. It's just that Republicans boast about selling out while Dems know they err and try to hid it.

So I don't wonder why people don't vote, I wonder why I go to the polls.

Like I said, I did vote. But I also live in the parallel reality of California, where all branches of state govt are dominated by Democrats. I can't affect Oklahoma state politics much. My question is: where was my national Democratic party while these shills were taking over in so many other states?
All manner of evil is possible when the majorty decide not to vote.
And the difference here?

Please come up here to Montana and ask some of the old timers about the very rapid rate of temperature changes and if they've ever seen anything like it. These are conservative ranchers and farmers and they are scratching their heads, wondering how their livelihoods will change and what they will be able to leave their children.

There are 3 things which continue to amaze me:
1. That any politician can state with a straight face that he is only operating in the best interest of the country or his constituents, all the while knowing he is beholden to corporate interests.
2. The audacity that these politicians and the SCOTUS claim that there is no quid pro quo with the involvement of such extreme amounts of money involved.
3. The naivete and complacency of a public that ignores the impact of the aforementioned practices and their influence on policy and our nation.

Where is the outrage? Where are the protests? Where are the change agents to say that enough is enough? I openly weep for our nation as it rots and decays before our eyes.
